Have you spent many moments thinking to yourself "you know, I'd REALLY like to see some innocent people graphically and violently maimed or slaughtered for no real rhyme or reason"? Is it fantasy you are after, or would you just like to fuel a sick mind?
 
 Well, I guess you have a few choices. Some people might act on the voices in their head, by joining the army and heading to Iraq, while others might simply venture down to their local video/DVD store. Assuming the latter, you will obviously notice an aisle... like a ray of sunshine... titled the "horror" section.
 
 I find it deeply disturbing that I live amongst a group of people that have a keen interest in seeing other people slaughtered in hard core horror movies. I've noticed even the most mild mannered Clark Kent type people can have this morbid fascination. Okay, so I have no problem seeing "The Running Man" slice and dice his way through an aggressor who was trying to give him a rectal chainsaw-ectomy, but that was clearly self defence! Now take a film about a chainsaw operator who likes to cut people because they give off a pretty red spray, and because he likes decorating his apartment with fresh corpses, without any ridiculous one liners, but just for the beautiful purity of gore. This simply cannot be an example of well intentioned entertainment.
 
 So if you're sitting there alone thinking "gosh, it's been hours since I've seen someone's head cut off with an angle grinder, I think I'd better go and rent a horror film", you need therapy... FAST.

valet_dave

I should clarify that I'm not saying people are incapable of distinguishing reality from fiction (well, the majority of people at least), but I am saying people need to question why this is seen as an acceptable form of entertainment. I've heard the convenient terms such as "visual art", but hard core horror films are simply products of a sick mind. Granted, the "special effects" in many of these films are of a professional standard, but they can never take the audience away from what is a flawed message. The only thing that makes sense, is the fact that movie makers can turn some profits by appealing to people who get off on senseless violence.
 
 Now before you cut me down with a blunt kitchen knife and gurgle my demon ridden blood in the name of your split personality, I do understand that violence surrounds our world, that is has been entrenched in our society since the beginning of existence. I can also see there are some educational uses for depicting high level violence in terms of understanding the horrible tragedy of war, persecution or criminal activity in the context of actual events, but somehow I don't think this is the focus of your average horror film. I am also not arguing that people don't have a right to watch what they want. What I am arguing is that we have a serious problem with people feeling a need to view other people senselessly killed. Is it curiosity, or just plain sadism?
 
 Surely we don't want our kids growing up watching material that essentially desensitizes them from what are heinous crimes. This is particularly relevant when the advancements in movie making technology have made these types of killings virtually indistinguishable, in the graphical sense, from actually being at the scene of such a crime. People are living these events, and more disturbingly, loving them.
 
 Now I can see there are some educational uses for depicting high level violence in terms of gaining some kind of understanding of the horrible tragedy of war, persecution or criminal activity, but somehow I don't think this is the focus of your average horror film. Sure people have a right to watch what they like, when they like, but there has to be questions asked when people feel a need to view other people being senselessly killed. Is it curiosity, or just plain sadism?
 
 I'm no pacifist, I accept that some disputes will inevitably involve bloodshed, simply because of the stubbornness, ignorance and lunacy that often provides the solid foundation for a brutal rampage. But this is hardly an activity that is worthy of promotion, even if we cloak it in true Hollywood style.
